name: isoamyl_formate
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.

name: isoamyl_formate
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.
Reason: The base unit for comparison is ethyl formate, which has a melting point of -81 degrees Celsius. Each additional carbon in the alkyl chain typically decreases the melting point by about 5 degrees, as larger alkyl groups increase the molecular weight and reduce the overall polarity, but they often make the molecule pack less efficiently in the solid state. Isoamyl formate has three more carbons in its alkyl chain compared to ethyl formate. However, due to the branching at the second carbon (isoamyl group), the molecule is even less able to pack efficiently in the solid state. This branching can impact the melting point equivalently to adding approximately 2-3 additional methylene groups, thereby lowering the melting point further by about 10-15 degrees.
